Anatoli,

The convective terms are upwinded and the diffusive terms are cen=
tral
differenced.  But this doesn't matter, if the energy equation was
solv=
ed in conservative form.  My understanding of this bug is that the
entire t=
rouble stems from the discretization of the term involving the
flux of sens=
ible enthalpy for each individual species, the term
involving c_p,k in the =
energy equation.  One would need to ensure
conservation of energy at each c=
ell interface.   In this case, once
the calculation is done, the enthalpy o=
f the products should be
EXACTLY equal to the enthalpy of the reactants on =
ANY grid, since in
the reactants and products, the diffusional fluxes vanis=
h and pressure
is imposed constant.

matei


--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com=
, "avmokhov" <avmokhov@...> wrote:
>
> 
> Hello,
> Last two days I was tryi=
ng to solve this problem. Indeed, for a free 
> hydrogen/air flame Cantera =
calculates temperatures substantially 
> lower than adiabatic ones (differe=
nce can be 40 K for a coarse grid). 
> It happens when multicomponent trans=
port is used. For a mixture-
> averaged model calculations are fine. Refini=
ng grid helps a little 
> bit - difference decreases down to 20 K when numb=
er of grid points 
> approaches 300. Further refinement is impossible: Cant=
era has 
> problems with the noise when approximating derivatives. It seems=
 for 
> me that something is nor correct with calculations of diffusion 
> =
terms. I did not dig in the code to check equations but it is 
> probably d=
ue to artificial diffusion on a coarse mesh. What 
> differences are used t=
o approximate derivatives? Windward or central 
> difference?
> Best regard=
s, Anatoli
> 
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Goodwin" <dgoodwin=
@> wrote:
> >
> > Could you send me an example flame script or program that=
 shows the 
> problem? Thanks.
> > 
> > --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Ma=
tei I. Radulescu" <matei@> wrote:
> > >
> > > When one computes the the fre=
e-flame structure (say H2+air at 
> PTN),
> > > the equilibrium temperature=
 obtained is different from the true
> > > adiabatic flame temperature obta=
ined via a direct equilibrium
> > > calculation, using the same thermo data=
.  The differences are on 
> the
> > > order of 10K for the example given. =
 Likewise, the enthalpy in the
> > > flame of the equilibrium products is N=
OT found equal to reactants
> > > enthalpy, although theoretically, they sh=
ould be equal.  This 
> leads me
> > > to suspect that the non-conservative=
 flame calculations introduces
> > > order 1 errors in the species concentr=
ations of the products,
> > > consistent with the results of the simulation=
s!  Are these
> > > *acceptable* errors???
> > >
> >
>
